headline: A review with good intentions
pros:
1)	Stable job and good absolute pay. Management is compassionate enough to retain those who are lagging in performance.
2)	Colleagues can become friends. These include people who would weather the storm as a team.
3)	Compensation and benefits are competitive if there is time to make claims.
4)	Mr Tsien is a very personable CEO with an eye for business growth. He works harder and longer hours than many others.
cons:
1)	Organizational restructuring plans dished out with no clear focus communicated to employees. 
2)	Suggestion to middle management to pull their socks up. Knee jerk reactions to customer and user issues usually result in after office hours investigations and team discussions circling around with minimal progression. More focus should be placed on long term sustainability plans but this has been neglected due to day-to-day fire-fighting and limited resources.
3)	Heavy reliance on a few key employees has resulted in an imbalance of workload.
4)	Employees‚Äô mental wellbeing taking a hit. Long hours (minimum 12 hours a day plus some weekends) are causing a toll on some employees and their families. There should be focus to improve the organizational culture after attempts to investigate and pinpoint to individual troubled employees.
5)	Department that is supposed to be at the forefront of technology has problem even obtaining basic working resources - laptop speed could be improved and delays in getting replacements when laptop has reached end of life. Hot desking concept implemented for a department for which people are expected to work quite frequently from office due to security and information access. Pen must be self-funded if needed.

headline: I hope everyone reads this before joining
pros: The salary and benefits are average. A good retirement ground (OCBC does not fire employees) - which leads to many people doing their minimal trying to past each day and things move very slowly.
cons:
1. This place is a top-down dictatorship and at the end of the day, the person at the top decides it all.

2. The top person puts numbers in front of its employees - Which explains the high turnover in the department (average of 5 to 6 staff tenders in the period of 6 to 8 months as an executive role, multiply that by 2 to 4 times for sales staff) Every employee is seen as a number not human. You‚Äôre expected to sell your life to the company and work even after 12 am into the weekends and even on your leave. What‚Äôs the point of giving you so many benefits when you don‚Äôt have the life to use it?

3. No foresight (Root of all evil) The management here has no foresight and constantly wants to be first in everything, which is good but what‚Äôs the point if you don‚Äôt maintain your first-mover advantage and launch a product which is flawed? Agile means launching a product with it‚Äôs essential/critical features are ready and not launching a broken product and fixing it AFTER it is launched. That is why there is so much firefighting over here and it is honestly a vicious cycle. You‚Äôre just firefighting because of the flawed process/product you have designed/launch initially which made the workload heavier instead of lessening the burden. (Then you blame your people for not hitting the KPI). As much as the acquisition is important, do allocate some money for your retention team and don't expect solutions to be free - What's the point of having a good striker if your goalkeeper allows the other team to keep scoring? 

4. Listen to your experts ‚Äì SCRUM Team is a team formed by specialists who are seasoned in their respective fields. You don‚Äôt design an entire system without input from any specialist but just a product manager just because you ‚ÄúLike/Trust‚Äù the PM and think that what you designed is what the customer wants with different officers calling you every day. Honestly, if I were a customer and you called me every single day just to ask me to accept your loan offer, I would go to a competitor bank with a more efficient service, better rates, and less irritating and seamless process. (Feels like I‚Äôm being nagged at by different teachers for the same homework every day) 

5. Honestly, this is one of the companies that still practice discriminatory hiring ‚Äì E.g Why does a First-Class Honours Graduate and 2nd Upper get paid differently when other banks have already scrapped this practice? (FYI, Diversity is not included in its core values) 

Overall, I cannot express how disappointed I am with this company. When you work here, it just feels like everything is way behind time

headline: Graduate Talent Programme (GTP) Experience

The GTP / MA programme at OCBC Bank has been a fruitful and fulfilling one. As a graduate talent of Group Operations & Technology division, the structured rotational programmes allowed me to have a meaningful stint in several technology roles, with exposure to risk and prevention efforts within the division.

Besides the technical aspects of work, the HR talent management has engaged us regularly to attend useful trainings to enhance our soft skills in areas of personal effectiveness, personal leadership and how to better manage our career growth in years to come.

There are also many opportunities to interact with and hear different perspectives from various OCBC's key leadership appointment holders at the annual graduate talent regional week, and meet our batch mates from overseas offices such as OCBC Malaysia and OCBC NISP. 

These are the many benefits that graduate talents could receive, as compared to normal direct hires into the various business units.

headline: Pros and Cons of working at OCBC Bank
pros: Family orientated culture and tightly knitted bunch of colleagues, perfect workplace for expectant mothers and people who want a stable job and fixed income. Most people are overall very friendly and appreciate internal cross department partnerships. Special mention to the CEO as I get the general sense that he really cares for his staff and the well being of most employees.
cons: Old fashioned way of working and slow to adapt and implement new technological and industry practices. Limited budget for implementation and very bureaucratic process of identifying problems and rolling out changes or updates. There is always a continual pressure on sales staff to value add to a sometimes uncompetitive product and pricing: this in turn causes fatigue in the long run. Personally, I feel that there is a risk that the organisation might slowly lag behind its competitors and other newer forms of banking or financial services if it keeps focusing on growing it's existing businesses the same old way without attempting to try new methods or technology.

headline: I used to be a manager in OCBC
pros:
Upper management seems keen on staff welfare. Time to time, staff will receive little goodies from the management, such as brownies, N95 mask. It is a good approach to know that the organisation still care about its staffs.

OCBC attempts to bring about colleagues cohesion with sport day, outings/
cons:
Commission payout is only verbal based and not written on anywhere, including the contract despite clearly being a commission incentive job. Payout will only be known months later and definitely lesser than the previous year. Staffs have no right to dispute if the payout is paid later than the verbal agreement, which is every quarterly, nor get a single cent if they choose to leave before the payout date.

Direct superior tends to micro manage and have apparent biases among subordinates. It felt like I am back in my primary school day where I are supposed to report every single movement.

Vulgarities were used on subordinates as and when the superior thinks it is necessary. Such as late reply to superior after working hours.

Double standard can be seen between top management and middle management. Subordinates like me, had to adhere to middle management (cutting corners and meeting KPIs) while lying to top management that we are adhering to theirs (delivering quality to consumers).

Feedback to the top management is equally controlled. Subordinates have to go through with their direct superiors what they are going to say and what is allowed. 

Internal transfer is only after 1.5 year - 2 years based on management approval hence only option for one to move out of the department is to wait and hope that OCBC approves your transfer or quit.
